text: [music playing]

LIZ MCCARTNEY: So we
are in central Louisiana

helping to rebuild the home
of Ms. Linda and Mr. Jesse.
He is a Vietnam vet.
They don't live in a flood zone.

They weren't expecting
this to happen.

LINDA MARCUS: We opted
for no flood insurance.

That was one of the
things we opted out of.

We've lived in this
home for 40 years.
We had never flooded.

NARRATOR: Over the course
of seven days in August,

nearly seven trillion
gallons of rain
pummeled southern Louisiana.
- Get my dog!

A sucker punch resulting
in the worst United States
disaster since Hurricane Sandy.
- I got your dog.
Oh!

LINDA MARCUS: We stayed in
the parking lot of the church
for the night.

And then the next morning,
the water was still coming up.

Our neighbor came over the
wooden fence in his boat,

and he took pictures and then
would send it to us so we could
see exactly how high it was.

NARRATOR: When the Marcus
family finally returned home,

their property and belongings
had been destroyed.

They were advised to gut their
home because of contamination
and health hazards.

LINDA MARCUS: We started with
wheelbarrows and shovels,

and started taking
everything to the road.

Our mountain of belongings
were put in a truck,

and we watched them lift it
and dump it in the truck.

Things that we've worked
all our lives for.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: We're setting
up an office in Baton Rouge

and working with
other organizations.

So we've been sending volunteers
back and forth from Baton Rouge

to support the immediate
recovery efforts there.

You're hired.
- Woo!
- OK.
All right.

LINDA MARCUS: I got a
call from Liz one day,

and everything [inaudible]
started falling into place.
LIZ MCCARTNEY: All right.

NARRATOR: For a full decade, our
first CNN Hero of the year, Liz

McCartney, has helped
families like the Marcus'
move back into their homes.
LIZ MCCARTNEY: Shazam!
Look at that!

NARRATOR: Liz started rebuilding
homes in 2006 in New Orleans
after Hurricane Katrina.

And she hasn't
stopped since then.

CNN Heroes honored Liz and
her organization, the St.
Bernard Project, in 2008.

Today, her organization
is called simply SBP.

And they're stronger
and larger than ever.
LIZ MCCARTNEY: Please join us.

Together we can continue
to rebuild families' homes
and lives.
Thank you.

We've rebuilt almost
12,000 houses,

with help from over
130,000 volunteers

from every state in the
country, from over 70 countries
from around the world.

It's been an extraordinary
outpouring of support.

SBP now works in seven different
disaster-impacted communities
across the country--

New York, New Jersey,
a community in Texas,

in Columbia, South Carolina,
in parts of West Virginia,

and now, most recently,
in Baton Rouge.

NARRATOR: Today,
disaster recovery
is Liz's full-time job.

And she and her team are
keenly focused on prevention
and safety as well.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: I think
we've learned over the years

that we have to dig
in and try to address
the root cause of the problem.

And actually, it's one of the
things I tell our partners now
in Baton Rouge.
And it always makes me cry.
It's going to make me cry now.

I say, you don't want to be
me in 10 and 1/2 years still
helping families get back home.

So let's figure
out how to do this

as efficiently, and as smartly,
and cooperatively as possible.
So yeah, it's been a journey.

NARRATOR: SBP launched
the Disaster Resilience

and Recovery Lab to
help home and business
owners prior to a disaster.

And afterwards, they're there
for homeowners, charities,

and government
officials to share
best practices and insight.

Over the years, SBP has also
started mental health support

groups, affordable housing
projects, and veterans
assistance programs.
- Yeah, I did.

NARRATOR: When CNN
Heroes met Liz,

the project was a
grassroots initiative.

Today, her team receives
support from major sponsors,

and SBP is recognized
internationally as a leader
in disaster recovery.

LIZ MCCARTNEY:
The Heroes Program

helped us help so many more
people, because it attracted

people to the organization and
was just a way to let folks

know that there's this huge need
out there in communities that
are impacted by a disaster.

And there's a way that they
can help very meaningfully that
will change people's lives.

NARRATOR: Today,
SBP's new headquarters

in the heart of New Orleans
is used as a hub for experts
to gather.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: How's
it coming, you guys?

NARRATOR: So far, SBP
has had more than 130,000

volunteers working on more than
1,000 projects across America.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: It's
going to be good.

NARRATOR: More than
half of these volunteers
have been in New Orleans.

TONY TRAPANESE: I've
worked on about a dozen

or so homes since
moving down here
in about an eight-month period.

It's easy to kind of assume
that everything has been taken
care of, but it's not true.

There's a lot of
work to be done.

It's inspiring seeing
those people who come
down here with real energy.
- Woo!

TONY TRAPANESE: Yeah,
I'm pretty excited too.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: The
reality is it's
all about having a great team.

And we're surrounded by
a lot of very dedicated,
extremely hardworking people.

NARRATOR: The fruits
of SBP's efforts

and other groups working in
New Orleans have paid off.

In many ways, the
city is thriving.

Tourists are back and new
businesses are opening.

But Liz says there are still
displaced residents more
than 10 years after Katrina--

people who want to
come home but can't.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: It's 11
years after Katrina,

and many neighborhoods
look like this one.
You know, they're vibrant.
People are back home.

Life is very much
back to normal.

I think the biggest
problem that we're seeing

is that we're still
working with families

who were impacted by Katrina
who are not home yet.

The real challenge is that
the overwhelming majority

of those people are victims
of contractor fraud,

or theft, or
vandalism, and they've
just run out of resources.

And they don't have
a clear path home.

ROBERTA HENDERSON: We
were here for Katrina.
We had 6 and 1/2 feet of water.

NARRATOR: Hurricane Katrina
struck in August of 2005,

leaving New Orleans and
its residents reeling.

CARL HENDERSON: When
I went in there,

it looked like somebody
had taken a bomb
and just blew up everything.
It was unbelievable.

NARRATOR: For 10
years, the Hendersons

struggled to rebuild
until they submitted
an application to SBP.

ROBERTA HENDERSON:
Someone called me

and she said, Mrs. Henderson,
we have your application

and we're going to help you
out to get back in your home.
This is the living room.
This is the dining room.
When I saw it, I was like, wow!
It's beautiful!

CARL HENDERSON: I had nothing
to do with the colors.
I do all the outside work.

NARRATOR: Liz McCartney
has spent the last decade

bearing witness to
Katrina's destruction

and helping flood
survivors find a path home.

She was recognized as a champion
of change by the White House.

And in January of
2013, Liz was one

of the citizen
co-chairs of President
Obama's second inauguration.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: I also am
always just like, it's not me.

We have this great team.
Right?
I don't know.

We get a lot of people
stepping up and saying,

I can do my part, and
I will do my part.

NARRATOR: For Liz McCartney and
co-founder Zach Rosenberg, who

continue to run the
organization together,

their professional
journey has been
mirrored by a personal one.

The co-founders got
married in 2010.

And today, they're raising
a family of their own
in New Orleans.

Liz says neither
journey was planned.

LIZ MCCARTNEY: When
Zach and I started,

we were naive enough
that we thought,

well, we'll just come down for
a little while and try to help.

And I never would have
imagined that we'd
still be here doing this work.

The thing that's always really
inspiring and a little bit

scary to me is when people
look me in the eye and say,

I'll keep coming until
you tell me to stop.

And I think, OK, I've got to
keep showing up every day then.

ANDERSON COOPER: Liz and her
team are doing tremendous work.

And we cannot wait to
see where they're going
to be in another 10 years.

CNN Heroes are nominated
by viewers like you.

Let us know who you think
deserves recognition for making
the world a better place.

Nominations are now
open at cnnheroes.com.
